timeline.message: For the Accumulation Checker directly implement QualifierHierarchy.
Merge branch 'graphHierarchy' of github.com:smillst/checker-framework into graphHierarchy

timeline.bodyText:
This statement doesn't seem right to me.  Are they like enum elements?  or is the set of all QualifierKinds like an enum?
Nit: "there" => "they"
timeline.author: mernst
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,120 @@ +package org.checkerframework.framework.util; + +import java.lang.annotation.Annotation; +import java.util.Set; +import org.checkerframework.checker.interning.qual.Interned; +import org.checkerframework.checker.nullness.qual.Nullable; +import org.checkerframework.framework.qual.AnnotatedFor; + +/** + * Represents a kind of qualifier, which is an annotation class. If two qualifiers use the same + * annotation class, then they have the same qualifier kind. Two qualifiers can have the same "kind" + * of qualifier but not be the same qualifier; an example is {@code @IndexFor("a")} and + * {@code @IndexFor("b")}. + * + *

A {@code QualifierKind} holds information about the relationship between itself and other + * {@link QualifierKind}s. + * + *

Exactly one qualifier kind is created for each annotation class. + * + *

QualifierKinds are like an enum in that there are immutable after initialization and only a

timeline.bodyText:
If this comment would be correct, could you add it?
// qualifierKind has no @SubtypeOf: it must be top or polymorphic
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: This contract is a bit confusing.  I suggest requiring that bottom is not null.  (See comment elsewhere.)
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: And not polymorphic?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Is a null return value always indicative of an error?  If so, should this throw?  That is what QualifierHierarchyWithElements does.  (The inconsistency is a bit surprising.)
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: No, this method could be used to check if an annotation is a qualifier in this hierarchy.
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText: My comment was a bit unclear, sorry.  I was asking whether it is ever used that way in the current code.  If not, maybe it could throw the exception to simplify all current clients.  (That would require creating a different method if we ever come up with a client that needs to do just a check.)
replies.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
bottom is nullable, but it is not documented what a null value means.
I suggest refactoring so that there are two public constructors, like the two current ones but all formal parameters are non-null.
Add a private constructor that they both call.  The private constructor may need a Void dummy argument to distinguish it from one of the public ones.  That is ugly, but less ugly than the current design which exposes an implementation detail to users and doesn't catch incorrect calls that pass null.
Only one of the public constructors will call setBottom, so setBottom can have non-null formal parameters and its contract is simplified.  (It's confusing to see setBottom called with null; I had to look up what it does in that case.)
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Could you make the comment a cross-reference, to make the comment more informative?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Since add returns a boolean, you could use it instead of contains, to make the code slightly shorter and slightly more efficient.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
Can you use allSupers and eliminate the visited variable?  It seems that the two collections will contain the same contents after the first iteration.
A possible fly in the ointment is the special treatment of polymorphic qualifiers.  Is it treated specially for the purposes of direct super types?  If so, should that be documented?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I don't think so. A QualifierKind is added to visited once its super qualifier kinds have been added to allSupers.  T allSupers contains QualifierKinds whose super qualifier kinds have not yet been added to allSupers.   But maybe I'm misunderstanding your comment.
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText: The code as is works, but I was wondering if it could be simplified.  Maybe a comment about the relationship between the variables is enough to help people understand the code.
replies.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: It's not clear what "initialized" means.  Later comments say "set while creating".  Could you make the comments consistent?  It would be good to avoid JVM jargon, if possible.  I think that this means until after the corresponding DefaultQualifierKindHierarchy has been created.
timeline.author: mernst
mernst

timeline.bodyText: The following 3 lines are used repeatedly.  How about adding an override of AnnotationUtils.createAnnotationSet() that takes a collection (or more likely an iterable) as an argument and returns an unmodifiable set?  Then you can use it here and elsewhere.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: I am curious why this does not use qualifierKindHierarchy.getTops().  The implementation in QualifierHierarchyWithElements does so and it would be good to keep the implementations in sync to the extent possible.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Why doesn't this use qualifierKindHierarchy.getBottoms()?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
It was slightly confusing that the following two methods appear in the opposite order in this file as they do in the superclass QualifierHierarchy.
It would also be nice to document (probably in QualifierHierarchy why both methods exist.  There are only two implementations of each method, and in each case one of the methods delegates to the other.  The naming seems arbitrary -- at least, the difference in names does not convey to me the difference in semantics, and I fear other programmers will be equally confused about which method they should use in a particular circumstance.  So clarifying that for clients would be helpful too.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
This if statement isn't actually needed.  (Or, are you leaving it in as a matter of style?)
Same comment applies to the following method.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: qualifierKindHierarchy.leastUpperBound(qual1, qual2) returns null if the qualifier kinds are not in the same hierarchy. For example, qual1 is @NonNull and qual2 is @Initialized.  (So the if statement is required.)
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText:
I agree that lub may be null.
My point is that kindToAnnotationMirror.get(lub) evaluates to null if lub is null, so the code will behave the same if this if statement is removed.
I'm OK with leaving it in if you prefer it as a matter of style.
replies.author: mernst

replies.bodyText:
My point is that kindToAnnotationMirror.get(lub) evaluates to null if lub is null, so the code will behave the same if this if statement is removed.

kindToAnnotationMirror will throw a NullPointerException if get is called with a null argument.
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText: OK.  Thanks for clarifying my misunderstanding.
replies.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Does it have to be "most"?  I think there are benefits if at least two (maybe at least one?) qualifiers have no elements/arguments.  Can you be more specific about when this class should be used?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I don't really have any more specific advice.  When I was convert all of the MultiGraphHierarchy subclass to one of the new classes, I only used this class when all but 1 or 2 qualifiers have elements.  Otherwise, it was easier to use QualifierHierarchyWithElements and write out all cases.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText:
The following fields, and some code, is duplicated or nearly so in the three QualifierHierarchy*.java implementations of the QualifierHierarchy interface.  I wonder whether it would make sense to create an abstract base class to avoid the code duplication.
This would reduce overall code duplication but would make it necessary to look at two classes (the abstract base class and its subclass) rather than one, to understand any particular implementation.  So, I am torn about this, but slightly inclined.  What do you think?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I think it's better to keep them separate.  In the past, we had many bugs where we assumed that qualifiers did not have elements, but they did.  If we have a single abstract class, we might make the same mistakes again.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: Should the two isInSameHierarchy calls always return the same value?  Or is it OK if they return different values?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: isSubtypeWithElements is only called when the subKind is a sub qualifier kind of superKind. (I just added that fact to the documentation.)  So the calls never return the different values.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText:
I find the comparison style that puts a constant on the lhs and a variable on the rhs looks funny.
That is, I dislike "if (4 == x || 5 == x)" and I prefer "if (x == 4 || x == 5)".  I don't have a great reason for my preference, except that is the way that we speak in English.  Is there a reason that you chose this order of arguments to ==?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
This is clever, but it is also surprising.  I would prefer to use a more straightforward coding pattern even if it is a bit more verbose.
The more verbose version will also probably be more efficient, because it can use two identity comparisons on interned strings.  The switch version always creates a new string, computes its hash code, and goes through every character if the hash code matches one of the cases -- none of which is necessary with the more verbose version.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Or QualifierHierarchyMostlyWithoutElements?
timeline.author: mernst
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -773,11 +681,32 @@ protected static QualifierHierarchy createQualifierHierarchy(
      * @return the {@link QualifierHierarchy} for this checker
      */
     public final QualifierHierarchy getQualifierHierarchy() {
-        // if (qualHierarchy == null)
-        //    qualHierarchy = createQualifierHierarchy();
         return qualHierarchy;
     }
 
+    /**
+     * To continue to use a subclass of {@link
+     * org.checkerframework.framework.util.MultiGraphQualifierHierarchy} or {@link
+     * org.checkerframework.framework.util.GraphQualifierHierarchy}, override this method so that it
+     * returns a new instance of the subclass. Then override {@link #createQualifierHierarchy()} so
+     * that it returns the result of a call to {@link
+     * org.checkerframework.framework.util.MultiGraphQualifierHierarchy#createMultiGraphQualifierHierarchy(AnnotatedTypeFactory)}.
+     *
+     * @param factory MultiGraphFactory
+     * @return QualifierHierarchy
+     * @deprecated Use either {@link
+     *     org.checkerframework.framework.util.QualifierHierarchyWithElements} or {@link
+     *     QualifierHierarchyWithoutElements} instead. This method will be removed in a future

timeline.bodyText: It is bad style to use Unqualified as the top annotation.  Can we create a new annotation to use here instead of using Unqualified.class?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: That would be better to do in a separate pull request.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: Should this be reverted?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Should this be reverted?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Should this commented code be deleted?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.message: Add a bit more to the changelog.
Fix Javadoc: use Outer.Inner for inner types
Merge branch 'graphHierarchy' of github.com:smillst/checker-framework into graphHierarchy
Merge branch 'refactorQualifierHierarchy' of github.com:smillst/checker-framework into refactorQualifierHierarchy
Merge branch 'graphHierarchy' of github.com:smillst/checker-framework into graphHierarchy

timeline.bodyText: Since this is only for elementless qualifiers, can you change the name to make that fact more clear?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Please make getter method and field have more similar names.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: The naming of fields and methods is a bit confusing.  The createTops method does not populate the tops field, though a reader might assume that.  Can you make the field names and method names more consistent?
timeline.author: mernst
mernst

replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: I think "are" should be either "at least one has" or "may be".
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: This is the same question as #3404 (comment), so I'm going to "resolve" this comment in favor of that one.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.message: Change the way bottom is set.
Fenum requires annotations in other classes.

timeline.bodyText: What about the other direction? If qualifier kinds are not subtypes, then is it guaranteed that the qualifiers of those kinds are not subtypes, right?
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: Could you split this into a top-level interface and then either a top-level AbstractQualifierKind class or a nested class in AbstractQualifierKindHierarchy?
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: This comment seems out of date.
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: Can you add a comment why this is a NavigableMap?
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: Could you extract an interface QualifierKindHierarchy and leave the implementation details in AbstractQualifierKindHierarchy?
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: I think I would add this to the individual fields. It's hard to miss here.
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: Is elements the best name for this? Would attributes be clearer?
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: Should the return type be @Interned?
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: Should this (and same for bottom below) throw a BugInCF? It's an error to call getTop before it was set.
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: Add a comment when this can be null.
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: I'm a bit confused by the ordering of methods. Shouldn't isTop be next to getTop?
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: How about return clazz.getSimpleName()?
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: The lub in this comment (and the glb below) should be plurals lubs/glbs to refer to the right fields.
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: Can we separate the hierarchy from the builder/factory that builds it, i.e. have two classes instead of mixing these two aspects?
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: uses should be use.
timeline.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: clazz.isAnonymousClass would be a more direct expression of the property you care about.
timeline.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: I care that name is not null.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: This method is private, so subclasses can't override or use this method.
timeline.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: This comment is to explain why it is private.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: For a few methods I was wondering why they are protected and not private. Should findLowestQualifiers be listed in the class documentation as an extension point? Or should it be private? Same for highest later.
timeline.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: findLowestQualifiers is protected because it is used by the Units Checker.  It's static, so it's not an extension point.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: Can we turn this into an interface?
timeline.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: I did this in #3445.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: Is this a TypeSystemError?
timeline.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: The framework itself could call this method with an incorrect annotation, so it could be a bug in the framework.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: Should these now be TypeSystemErrors?
timeline.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: Ping.
replies.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: This could be a bug in QualifierKindHierarchy or ComplexQualifierHierarchy, so it should stay a BugInCF.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.message: Make QualifierKindHierarchy an interface. Move QualiferKind to top level.

timeline.bodyText: I don't understand this. If a1 is Fenum, but a2 is not Fenum, we could still have that a2 is FenumTop. Then, shouldn't the LUB be FenumTop?
timeline.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: This method is only called when the LUB of the two QualifierKinds is a QualifierKind that has elements.  The LUB(@Fenum("a"), @FenumTop) is @FenumTop, so this method isn't called. I improved the documentation on the super class for this method.  It wasn't clear enough.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.message: Add method that uses the old QualifierHierarchy.

timeline.bodyText: It was unclear whether QualifierKindHierarchy represents a single qualifier hierarchy (that's what the name implied to me), or a set of qualifier hierarchies (I think this is correct, because tops and bottoms are sets rather than singletons), or just contains utility methods.  Please clarify and possibly rename the class.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: [Just document that there may be more than one hierarchy.]
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText:
The terminology "kind" is not explained in the documentation.  Given that the documentation says that QualifierKind represents a class, how about renaming this to "QualifierClass" or even "Qualifier"?
(I think you are making a distinction between (1) concrete qualifier uses or instantiations in the programmer's source code and (2) a "kind" that represents many possible instantiations.  But it took me a while to come to this understanding.)
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText:
I had originally named this class "QualifierClass", but it is confusing because a qualifier class would have type Class<Annotation>. For example, see the constructor of QualifierKindHierarchy.
This class does not represent a "Qualifier" because a qualifier may have values for the annotation elements, but QualifierKinds do not.  So @Regex(1) is a qualifier but it can't be represents by this class.
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText:
I also found the Kind part confusing - in other places, like in Tree.Kind the Kind is some enum that distinguishes different, well, kinds of trees.
What about QualifierTemplate, QualifierMold, QualifierPrototype, or QualifierArchetype?
replies.author: wmdietl

replies.bodyText: TODO: Document why it's called kind.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: Regarding @Interned:  is it possible that two different QualifierKindHierarchy objects exist, each of which creates a QualifierKind for the same Class?  If not, what prevents that?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: No.  Its constructor is private and the Interning Checker, which is run in CI, reports only one error in #createQualifierKinds.  See that method for why that warning is suppressed.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText:
Does this represent a forall relationship (every instantiation of a QualifierKind in superTypes is a supertype of every instantiation of this) or an exists relationship (some instantiation of a QualifierKind in superTypes is a supertype of some instantiation of this)?
For example, " can imagine that some instantiations of QualifierKind Super are supertypes of some instantiations of QualifierKind Sub; for example, @Super("a") is a supertype of @Sub("a"), but @Super("b") is not a supertype of @Sub("a").  How would that be represented here?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Is this reflexive or strict subtype?  Please clarify in the documentation.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Every existing clients calls this method and then immediately calls get or values on the result.  Do type systems need access to this map?  You could provide two methods that do the things that clients want, which is to look up by name or to get all the QualifierKinds.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Is this a fully-qualified name or a canonical name?  The name field of QualifierKind is documented as a canonical name.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: I suggest that you dispense with the QualifierKindPair class.  Instead, make the type of lubs be Map<QualifierKind, Map<QualifierKind, QualifierKind>>.  Instead of lubs.get(new QualifierKindPair(q1, q2)), clients will call lubs.get(q1).get(q2).  This will be more efficient for clients because they do not have to spend the time to create, then garbage-collect, many QualifierKindPair objects.  Also, don't do any sorting of the elements in the pair:  just represent both orders redundantly in the maps.  That will also save a small amount of computation.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: What is the format of the annotation name?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Can also be null, in which case this method has no effect.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: I would rename superTypes to directSuperTypes for clarity.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Why does this add/augment rather than replacing?  Why does it add all of directSuperMap's keySet, when some of those values might not be direct supertypes of bottom?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: How can this be necessary?  That is, how can bottomKind be one of its own direct supertypes?  directSuperMap should have no self-mappings.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: The line above adds the keySet of directSuperMap to superTypes, so it has to be removed.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: This has some other side effects:  it sets or augments the given class's super qualifiers from directSuperMap.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: Added below.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText:
Also sets the top field, but only for top annotations. Please document that.
I find this design a bit surprising.  Why not set all the top fields in the same method?  I think that might be conceptually simpler, but maybe I am missing something important about the current design.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: I find this confusing.  What does the user-written source code look like when this if condition evaluates to true?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
What does "supported" mean?  Should this just say that the qualifier is not in the hierarchy?
Also change $s to %s (that was my typo, sorry).
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Can you call Collections.singleton instead?  That is more efficient.  Use of these two lines implies that it is important to clients that the superTypes field is modifiable.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: As I noted elsewhere, I found it surprising that the top field is set for tops elsewhere, and here for all non-tops.  I would put them all in the same place.  Or, document the design.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: They are all set here now.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: This logic does not find all cycles.  For example, suppose there is qualifierKind -> A -> B -> A.  This will infinite-loop because superQual will ping-pong between A and B but never be equal to qualifierKind.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: I added logic to break this loop.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: When reading this, I was confused abouh how this can happen.  I think the answer is that QualifierKindPair canonicalizes the order of the elements of the pair.  With the elimination of that class that I suggested, this will not be relevant any more.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: This logic is a bit inefficient.  I think that's OK because this version is only ever called once per pair, at the beginning of the Checker Framework run, and the result is cached.  Explaining when various methods will be called would be useful to help readers understand the design.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: Why isn't this an error?  (All comments about lub apply to corresponding glb methods too.)
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.message: Use Annotation.class as default value for PolymorphicQualifier.

timeline.bodyText: I don't understand what "[]" means in this comment (and in other similar comments).
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: Ping on this comment.
replies.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
It is more efficient to break; right after this increment operation.
(Alternately, you could abstract out the inner loop into a separate method, and there would be no need for a count variable.  It might be a bit less efficient because of the method calls, but would be more efficient in being able to exit early rather than checking all type hierarchies.)
Same comment applies in 3 other places in the pull request.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: Ping on this comment.
replies.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: This code assumes that kind is a key in getTopToPoly(), but there is no guarantee that start is a top.  (The specification of this method in QualifierHierarchy does not demand it.)
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
areInSameHierarchy reads strangely to me, since the "subject" of the "sentence" is subKind which is singular.
How about renaming the method to inSameHierarchyAs or isInSameHierarchyAs or the like?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
Please write Javadoc documentation for all methods.
The next two methods need it, too.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: I think this should be kind == null.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: I wondered why this used a TreeSet.  It's not obviously more efficient.  Is it because you want the method to return the qualifiers in a deterministic order?  The Javadoc doesn't promise it.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Be specific about the needed fix, similarly to the errors in the previous two cases.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Why is this required?  Since the QualifierKind class is annotated as @Interned, I expect its constructor to return an @Interned object.  Am I incorrect about that?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: The type of the constructor result is @UnknownInterned.  See the manual.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: You suggested adding a TypeSystemError to complement BugInCF and UserError.  I think that is a good thing to do, in a separate pull request that is merged before this one.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: It bugs me a bit that when we speak of subtypes, it is a reflexive operation, but when we speak of supertypes, it is strict (non-reflexive).  This lack of symmetry is confusing.  We could imagine renaming this method to getStrictSuperTypes.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.message: Merge branch 'graphHierarchy' of github.com:smillst/checker-framework into graphHierarchy

timeline.bodyText: Putt getter/setter methods in the same order as the fields.  (Change one or the other.)
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: top and bottom are fields in QualifierKind, but poly information is in this external field.  Would it make sense to make poly a field in QualifierKind too?  Then there would not be the need to translate to top and look up in an external map.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText:
I don't see any clients that require this to be sorted -- all the clients do their own sorting too.
(I don't object to this, but I wonder why it is necessary.  Is it to make logging and diagnostics deterministic?  Or is it just a side effect of the implementation, and we tell clients in case they can take advantage of it?)
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: Many methods iterate over the collection and throw TypeSystemErrors.  It's sorted so those exceptions are deterministic.
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText: Should the return type be List then?
replies.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: This code treats the absence of @SubtypeOf identically to @SubtypeOf() or @SubtypeOf({}).  I think that's OK, but the Javadoc says to always write @SubtypeOf({}).  I suggest that we adjust the Javadoc and the manual to indicate that omitting @SubtypeOf is OK.  Or do we want to require an empty @SubtypeOf annotation on the top type, for emphasis?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText:
This code treats the absence of @SubtypeOf identically to @SubtypeOf() or @SubtypeOf({})

That's not true.  If an annotation class does not have a @Subtype, then it is not added to the directSuperType map.  If a qualifier is not a polymorphic qualifier nor in the directSuperTypes map, then QualifierKindHierarchy#verifyHierarchy throws a TypeSystemError.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: The argument to @PolymorphicQualifier is by convention the top qualifier, but that is not required.  This code assumes it is the top qualifier and I think the code will misbehave (eg, by making a non-top qualifier a key in topsToPoly) if it is not.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: The argument to @PolymorphicQualifier should always be a top qualifier.  I changed the documentation.  The old implementation assumes it is top. This implementation will throw a TypeSystemError (in QualifierKindHierarchy#verifyHierarchy) if it is not top.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: Does the end of this for loop need an if (qualifierKind.bottom == null) test like the if (qualifierKind.top == null) above?
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: The names "Simple" and "Complex" are not very evocative.  How about "NoElements..." and "Elements...", or "...WithoutElements" and "...WithElements"?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText:
I'm still thinking on this.
SimpleQualifierHierarchy:

NoElementsQualifierHierarchy
QualifierHierarchyWithElements
DefaultQualifierHierarchy (Because it's the QualifierHierarchy used by default.)

ComplexQualifierHierarchy:

ElementsQualifierHierarchy
QualifierHierarchyWithElements
QualifierWithValuesHierarchy
replies.author: smillst

replies.bodyText: The suffixed versions QualifierHierarchyWithoutElements and QualifierHierarchyWithElements read best to me, among the options you list.
replies.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: QualifierHierarchyWithoutAttributes and QualifierHierarchyWithAttributes?
replies.author: wmdietl

timeline.bodyText: Is this called frequently?  If so, would it make sense to create a map, for efficiency?
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: Yes, it's called often, but most AnnotationMirrors are instances of CheckerFrameworkAnnotationMirror.  In those cases, AnnotationUtils.annotationName returns the annotationName field.  If it's not a CheckerFrameworkAnnotationMirror, the it's an annotation from bytecode.  In those cases there are many AnnotationMirror objects for the same qualifiers, so a map isn't helpful.
replies.author: smillst

timeline.bodyText: Should this be TypeSystemError?  Similar question about some other uses of BugInCF.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: No, the methods in this class are called by the Checker Framework during type checking.  So although these could be a bug in the type system, it is just as likely a bug in the Checker Framework.  (I'll check other uses of BugInCF in this file.)
replies.author: smillst

timeline.message: Merge branch 'refactorQualifierHierarchy' of github.com:smillst/checker-framework into refactorQualifierHierarchy

Merge remote-tracking branch 'remotes/origin/master' into graphHierarchy

# Conflicts:
#	framework/src/main/java/org/checkerframework/framework/source/SourceChecker.java
#	framework/src/main/java/org/checkerframework/framework/type/AnnotatedTypeFactory.java
